title: **unrepx** package for R
text: unrepx package provides much one needs analyze basic unreplicated screening experiments two-level factorial fractional factorial designs, one set independent effect estimates degrees freedom error. analyses based underlying assumptions effect estimates: independent variance normally distributed Many effects inactive (negligible), minority active (non-negligible). requirement known effect-sparsity assumption. first last important. several cases effects independent – among Plackett-Burman designs definitive screening designs – software needed. without effect-sparsity assumption, one needs replications, assumption, order assess effects likely active. document provides overview examples. user consult help pages details finer points.

title: **unrepx** package for R
text: functions yates() gyates() allow estimation effects without also providing design matrix. Instead, response values must arranged standard order, whereby first factor varies fastest, second second fastest, . See help("yates") details functions, well literature references. example, consider pilot-plant example given text Box, Hunter, Hunter (2nd ed.), page 177. experiment involves three factors T, C, K, two levels. estimate effects factors process yield, providing response values standard order (presented text): Note 7 effects 8 experimental runs; mean added attribute. yates() gyates() functions can also reverse produce original response values, given effects. decide based length data provided.
code: require("unrepx") ## Loading required package: unrepx ( pilotEff = yates(c(60,72,54,68,52,83,45,80), labels = c("T","C","K")) ) ##    T    C   TC    K   TK   CK  TCK  ## 23.0 -5.0  1.5  1.5 10.0  0.0  0.5  ## attr(,"mean") ##        ## 64.25 yates(pilotEff) ## --- +-- -+- ++- --+ +-+ -++ +++  ##  60  72  54  68  52  83  45  80

title: **unrepx** package for R
text: unrepx provides three graphical tools helping identify active effects: [half]-normal plots, reference plots, Pareto plots. Half-normal normal plots available via hnplot() (see details help page). half-normal plot effects just computed, labels added exceed 10:  default, reference line added (see section statistics details). dots colored blue positive red negative effects. Visually, appears T TK effects active, appear outliers. Ordinary normal plots possible , strongly discourage using can misleading. reference plot dotplot effects, along reference curve. default, absolute effects plotted along half-normal curve:  -product, general-purpose dot.plot function also provided. plots resizeable directions: vertical resize, dots re-stacked correct spacing; horizontal resize, dots may re-binned. Pareto plots produced using parplot(). plot bar graph bars ordered size effect. addition, cutoff line(s) added margin error () simultaneous margin error (SME) effects (see section statistics).
code: hnplot(pilotEff, ID = 10) title("Half-normal plot of the pilot-plant effects") refplot(pilotEff, ID = 10) title("Reference plot of the pilot-plant effects") parplot(pilotEff)  title("Pareto plot of the pilot-plant effects")

title: **unrepx** package for R

PSE() function calculates estimates. See help("PSE") list available methods. default Zahn method based slope line origin fitted smallest 2/3 points half-normal plot. PSE estimate, one can compute t-like statistic via dividing effect estimate PSE. turn, associated reference distribution can estimated simulating t statistics independent inactive effects. (can accessed like via ref.dist() function; see help page. Ordinarily, though, needed simulations done – stored – background needed.) high percentile (typically 95th) reference distribution |t| provides critical value. critical value, multiplied PSE, gives margin error assessing effects. value used obtaining cutoff line labeled “” Pareto plot. one instead uses instead distribution max|t| simulated set effects, simultaneous margin error (SME) results. idea happens effects inactive, unlikely |t| ratios exceed SME. , observe effects , pretty convincing evidence indeed active effects mix. case pilot-plant example, can see Pareto plot . non-graphical analysis showing observed t ratios, along P values obtained tail areas reference distribution, available via eff.test():

title: **unrepx** package for R
text: Several sets example effects provided package: "bikeEff"“, "pdEff"”, "shnkEff", "shnkDisp"“, "viseEff" (see help("bikeEff") details). Finally, anyone wishing construct half-normal plots hand, originally done Daniel’s 1959 paper, daniel.paper() function provides suitable graph paper purpose.
code: daniel.paper(15)

title: Authors and Citation
text: Lenth R (2024). unrepx: Analysis Graphics Unreplicated Experiments. R package version 1.0-3, https://rvlenth.github.io/unrepx/, https://github.com/rvlenth/unrepx.
code: @Manual{,   title = {unrepx: Analysis and Graphics for Unreplicated Experiments},   author = {Russell Lenth},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 1.0-3, https://rvlenth.github.io/unrepx/},   url = {https://github.com/rvlenth/unrepx}, }

what: Analysis and Graphics for Unreplicated Experiments
title: Analysis and Graphics for Unreplicated Experiments
text: URL: https://rvlenth.github.io/unrepx/

title: Analysis and Graphics for Unreplicated Experiments
text: Russ Lenth, University Iowa, russell-lenth@uiowa.edu unrepx package provides much one needs analyze basic unreplicated screening experiments two-level factorial fractional factorial designs, one set independent effect estimates degrees freedom error. analyses based underlying assumptions effect estimates independent normal, variance; effect sparsity holds whereby effects active. package provides basic functions yates() gyates() estimating effects; plotting functions hnplot() (half-normal plot), refplot() (reference plot), parplot() (Pareto plot) displaying effects depicting may active; statistical analysis functions PSE() (pseudo standard error), () (margin error), ref.dist() (reference distribution), eff.test() (tests effects). dot.plot() function underlies ref.plot() also usable right creating resizeable dot plots. also example effect estimates, function creating half-normal graph paper. see overview features, use vignette("overview", package = "unrepx"). may also view , without graphs

title: Analysis and Graphics for Unreplicated Experiments
text: install latest version CRAN (available ), run install latest development version Github, newest devtools package installed, run latest release notes development version, see NEWS file
code: install.packages("unrepx") devtools::install_github("rvlenth/unrepx", dependencies = TRUE, build_vignettes = TRUE)

what: Pseudo standard error of effects — PSE
title: Pseudo standard error of effects — PSE
text: Computes pseudo standard error using variety built-methods, user-supplied one.

title: Pseudo standard error of effects — PSE
code: PSE(effects, method = "Zahn", verbose = FALSE)  ME(effects, method = "Zahn", alpha = .05, ...)

title: Pseudo standard error of effects — PSE
text: effects Numeric vector effects contrasts explored. method Character value. name method used. See Details. verbose Logical value. TRUE, parameters () generated method's setup code printed. alpha Numeric significance level, 0 1. ... Additional arguments passed ref.dist. matching reference distribution already available .Last.ref.dist, arguments effect.

title: Pseudo standard error of effects — PSE
text: PSE function implements methods estimating standard error effects estimates unreplicated designs. underlying assumption effects variance, “effect sparsity” assumption applies, whereby majority effects inactive handful active. method may “directed” method (described Hamada Balakrishnan (1998). number built-methods available; see list . Users may easily write method. method "foo" implemented writing function foo_pse <- function(effects) { ... } saving can found search path. example can found listing unrepx:::Lenth_pse. user-supplied function needs use weights, coefficients, parameters depend length(effects) cumbersome simulations (e.g., ref.dist), user may instead provide function foo_pse <- function(effects, parm) { ... }, along attr(foo_pse, "setup") <- function(n.effects) { ... } returns parm argument (say, list) used length(effects) = n.effects. setup function called automatically "setup" attribute exists, , function expected second argument. See listing unrepx:::Zahn_pse example.

title: Pseudo standard error of effects — PSE
text: PSE returns single numeric value, named style method_PSE. returns named numeric vector length 2, containing margin error simultaneous margin error SME.

title: Pseudo standard error of effects — PSE
text: Daniel 68.3rd quantile absolute effects. See Daniel (1959). Dong RMS method, applied excluding effects exceed 2.5 * PSE(effects, "SMedian") absolute value. See Dong (19??). JuanPena iterated median method whereby repeatedly calculate median absolute effects exceed 3.5 times previous median, stabilizes. estimate final median, divided .6578. See Juan Pena (1992). Lenth SMedian method, applied excluding effects exceed 2.5 * PSE(effects, "SMedian") absolute value. See Lenth (1989). RMS Square root mean squared effects. good PSE presence active effects, provided sake comparisons. SMedian 1.5 times median absolute effects. Zahn, WZahn Zahn method slope least-squares line fitted first \(m\) points hnplot(effects, horiz = FALSE), m = floor(.683 * length(effects)). (line fitted origin.) WZahn method experimental version Zahn's method, based weighted least-squares weights decreasing linearly \(m - .5\) \(.5\), bounded \(.65m\).

title: Pseudo standard error of effects — PSE
text: Daniel, C (1959)   Use Half-Normal Plots Interpreting Factorial Two-Level Experiments.   Technometrics, 1(4), 311-341 Dong, F (1993)   Identification Active Contrasts Unreplicated Fractional Factorials.   Statistica Sinica 3, 209-217 Hamada Balakrishnan (1998)   Analyzing Unreplicated Factorial Experiments:   Review New Proposals.   Statistica Sinica 8, 1-41 Juan, J Pena, D (1992)   Simple Method Identify Significant Effects Unreplicated   Two-Level Factorial Designs.    Communications Statistics: Theory Methods 21, 1383-1403 Lenth, R (1989)   Quick Easy Analysis Unrelicated Factorials   Technometrics 31(4), 469-473 Zahn, D (1975)   Modifications Revised Critical Values Half-Normal Plot.   Technometrics 17(2), 189-200

title: Resizeable dot plots — dot.plot
text: Flexible stacked-dot plots relatively small samples, provisions identifying points. dot plot responsive resizing plot window: vertical resizing affect vertical spacing dots, horizontal resizing may lead re-binning fit well within range.

title: Resizeable dot plots — dot.plot
code: dot.plot(x, pch = 16, cex.dot = 1, spacing = 1, xlab, xlim = range(x), ...)  dot.id(env, height.id = 2, cex.id = 1, col.id = "black") dot.mod(env, ...)

title: Resizeable dot plots — dot.plot
text: x Numeric vector values plotted. pch Plotting character dots. Default filled circle. cex.dot Size dots relative par("cex"). spacing Factor adjusting vertical spacing stacked dots. xlab, xlim usual graphical parameters (see par), used dot.plot dot.id. env Environment returned dot.plot. height.id Height (character heights) horizontal axis displaying identification labels. cex.id, col.id cex col settings labeling identified points. ... dot.plot, additional graphical parameters (see par) used constructing plot. dot.mod, parameters modify, among cex.dot, cex.id, col.id, height.id.

title: Resizeable dot plots — dot.plot
text: dot.id dot.mod work interactive graphics devices. dot.id works similarly identify, dots particular stack identified . user click along bottom row dots. labels displayed user exits identify mode (may necessary refresh plot resizing slightly). Also, points labeled may change plot resized horizontally, x values actually identified. user may call dot.id(..., modify = FALSE) , desired change values identified. call dot.id (especially) dot.mod, graph may need refreshed. appears standard way , user may need resize window slightly.

title: Resizeable dot plots — dot.plot
text: dot.plot returns environment used hold information points identified. dot.id modifies environment; (invisibly) returns currently identified x values. (values original call dot.plot, rounded values used plot.)

title: Resizeable dot plots — dot.plot
text: Russell V. Lenth

title: Resizeable dot plots — dot.plot
code: require("unrepx")  educ = swiss$Education names(educ) = abbreviate(row.names(swiss)) dp <- dot.plot(educ, xlab = "Percent Post-Primary Education (Switzerland, 1888)")   if (FALSE) {     dot.id(dp)          dot.mod(dp, height.id = 3, cex.id = .5) }

title: Effect examples — pdEff
text: Published simulated examples effects.

title: Effect examples — pdEff
code: pdEff bikeEff viseEff shnkEff shnkDisp

title: Effect examples — pdEff
text: named numeric vector effect estimates unreplicated experiments.     Also, additional mean attribute containing response mean.

title: Effect examples — pdEff
text: pdEff vector 15 effects four-factor experiment process development. experiment described Box, Hunter, Hunter (2005), Section 5.13, effects tabulated Table 5.11, page 200. response variable conversion percent, experiment involves one replication combination four two-level factors: catalyst charge (C), temperature (T), pressure (P), concentration (c). (text labels factors 1, 2, 3, 4 elected use suggestive alphabetic labels.) effects standard (Yates) order. bikeEff vector 7 effects saturated experiment 8 runs 7 two-level factors. experiment described Box, Hunter, Hunter (2005), Section 6.5 effects reported Table 6.5, page 245. response variable time required climb particular hill, factors seat height, dynamo, gear, handlebars, raincoat, breakfast, tires. (Effect labels abbreviations .) effects standard order first, second, fourth factors. viseEff vector 15 effect estimates fictitious experiment, simulated package developer. effects labeled alphabetically, -O, stanradr order , B, D, H. shnkEff, shnkDisp Vectors location dispersion effects, respectively, speedometer-cable shrinkage example discussed Box, Hunter, Hunter (2005), Section 6.14. vector length 15. effect names 4-letter abbreviations factor names. Effects computed anew data Table 6.18: shnkEff “Average” response shnkDisp “Log Variance” response. table book actually gives variances, log variances, logs taken dispersion effects calculated. effect values differ somewhat book.

title: Effect examples — pdEff
text: Box, GEP, Hunter, JS, Hunter, WG (2005) Statistics Experimenters (2nd ed) New York: John Wiley & Sons

title: Effect examples — pdEff
code: require("unrepx")  parplot(bikeEff, method = "Zahn")   opar <- par(mfcol = c(1,2))   hnplot(shnkEff, half = FALSE, main = "Normal plot")   hnplot(shnkEff, half = TRUE, main = "Half-Normal plot")  #   Why ordinary normal plots are a bad idea #   Both plots have the same reference line par(opar)  # Note - Examples in help pages for hnplot, parplot, refplot, and eff.test #        use pdEff for illustration  if (FALSE) {     # Do try this at home:     hnplot(viseEff, ID = TRUE)     refplot(viseEff, ID = TRUE) }

what: Half-normal plots (Daniel plots) of effects — hnplot
title: Half-normal plots (Daniel plots) of effects — hnplot
text: hnplot function constructs (half-) normal plot effects (see Daniel 1959) traditionally used identify active effects screening experiment. Reference lines various options extensions supported.

title: Half-normal plots (Daniel plots) of effects — hnplot
code: hnplot(effects, ref = TRUE, half = TRUE, horiz = TRUE, method = "Zahn",         a = 0.375, col = half, pch = 16, ID = FALSE, alpha, ...)

title: Half-normal plots (Daniel plots) of effects — hnplot
text: effects Numeric vector effects contrasts explored. ref Logical value. TRUE, reference line added plot determined method. FALSE, reference shown. half Logical value. TRUE, plot based absolute effects constructed. FALSE (recommended: see Details), original signed effects used. horiz Logical value. TRUE, (absolute) effects plotted horizontal scale (half-) normal scores labels plotted vertical scale. FALSE, axes reversed. method Character value. ref TRUE, method use determining reference line, curve, /critical values. must name provided pseudo-standard-error method (see PSE), compatible user-supplied one. adjustment used scaling centering ranks interval (0, 1). \(\)th ordered (half-) normal score computed \((- ) / (n + 1 - 2*)\) quantile reference distribution. col Scalar vector colors; logical value. logical, value TRUE colors positive effects blue, negative effects red, zeros black. logical value FALSE colors black. pch Plotting character(s) use. alpha Numeric value. specified, null reference distribution method used (see ref.dist) determine margin error (labeled ‘’) simultaneous margin error (labeled ‘SME’) corresponding significance level alpha, reference lines added plot positions aid assessing statistical significance effects. based suggestion Mee (2015). reference lines omitted alpha left unspecified. ID Logical numeric value. logical TRUE, plot contructed, plot put identify mode, user may click points labeled plot. numeric value supplied, used threshold effects greater ID[1] absolute value labeled. ... Additional graphical parameters (see par) used constructing plot.

title: Half-normal plots (Daniel plots) of effects — hnplot
text: Use half = FALSE recommended can misleading user. Inactive effects close zero, regular normal plot displays deviations normality rather deviations zero.

title: Half-normal plots (Daniel plots) of effects — hnplot

text: Russell V. Lenth

title: Half-normal plots (Daniel plots) of effects — hnplot
code: require("unrepx")  hnplot(pdEff, ID = ME(pdEff))

title: Half-normal graph paper — daniel.paper
text: daniel.paper function draws graph-paper grid suitable manually constructing half-normal plot effects. paper customized number effects plotted, thus making task simple possible.

title: Half-normal graph paper — daniel.paper
code: daniel.paper(n.effects = 15, linear = 0:40, a = 0.375,      rank.axis = c("y", "x"), type = c("half.normal", "normal"),      theme = "blue", lin.lab, rank.lab)

title: Half-normal graph paper — daniel.paper
text: n.effects Numeric vector effects contrasts explored. linear sequence numbers use linear scale. adjustment used scaling centering ranks interval (0, 1). \(\)th ordered (half-) normal score computed \((- ) / (n + 1 - 2*)\) quantile reference distribution. value always less 1, recommended [0,.5]. scale becomes somewhat nonlinear \(\) increases. rank.axis Character value "y" "x" selecting whether ranks effects plotted vertical horizontal coordinate. type Character value matching "half.normal" "normal" specifying whether scaling half-normal normal plot. latter recommended. theme Character giving name theme use grid lines. default "blue" plots major grid lines blue minor ones cyan. built-themes "bw" (black majors, dotted black minors), "gray" (black majors gray minors), "bold" (lines black, major lines heavier). See details information create one's theme. lin.lab, rank.lab Labels linear rank scales.

title: Half-normal graph paper — daniel.paper
text: Use type = "normal" discouraged, discussed Details section hnplot. custom theme, say "foo", may created creating list named foo_thm, contain two elements named major minor, (optionally) axis. major must named list graphical parameters col, lty, lwd described par. minor requires col lty, minor lines always drawn using lwd = 1. axis must contain col lwd, used tick marks labels rank scale. axis included, major used.

title: Half-normal graph paper — daniel.paper
text: Nothing returned.

title: Half-normal graph paper — daniel.paper
text: Daniel, C (1959)   Use Half-Normal Plots Interpreting Factorial Two-Level Experiments.   Technometrics, 1(4), 311-341

title: Half-normal graph paper — daniel.paper
text: Russell V. Lenth

title: Half-normal graph paper — daniel.paper
code: require("unrepx")  old.par <- par(mar = c(5, 5, 1, 1) + .1) daniel.paper(15)   neon_thm <- list(     major = list(col = "green", lty = 1, lwd = 2),     minor = list(col = "orange", lty = 1),     axis = list(col = "magenta", lwd = 2) ) daniel.paper(31, rank.axis = "x", theme = "neon") #> Error in get(paste0(theme, "_thm")): object 'neon_thm' not found  par(old.par)

title: Pareto plot of effects — parplot
text: Constructs bar plot ordered effects, along cutoff values margin error () simultaneous margin error (SME). plot suggested Lenth (1989), methods may used obtaining SME.

title: Pareto plot of effects — parplot
code: parplot(effects, pareto = TRUE, absolute = TRUE, horiz = FALSE, col = absolute,     critvals, method = "Zahn", alpha = .05, refdist, sim.opts,      ylab = "Estimated effects", top = n.effects, cex.annot = 0.75, ...)

title: Pareto plot of effects — parplot
text: effects Numeric vector effects contrasts explored. pareto Logical value. TRUE, effects plotted decreasing order absolute values. absolute Logical value. TRUE, absolute effects plotted. FALSE, original signed effects used, potentially positive- negative-going bars plot. horiz Logical value. TRUE, bars horizontal, FALSE, vertical. col logical value, valid color code(s) names(s). logical, value TRUE shades positive effects light blue, negative effects pink. logical value FALSE colors light gray. critvals Numeric value(s). provided, first two elements critvals used SME respectively (absolute scale effects). critvals specified, method, alpha, refdist ignored. method Character value designating method use determining margins error displayed plot critvals given. must name provided pseudo-standard-error method (see PSE), compatible user-supplied one. alpha Numeric value. null reference distribution method used (see ref.dist) determine margin error (labeled ‘’) simultaneous margin error (labeled ‘SME’) corresponding significance level alpha, reference lines added plot positions aid assessing statistical significance effects. refdist result ref.dist. given, used obtain critical values, rather running new simulation null distribution. user careful refdist indeed matches method number effects. sim.opts list containing arguments nsets /save pass ref.dist case new reference distribution needs simulated. See also details . ylab Character axis label (overrides default). top Numeric value giving number effects display (may help make important effect names visible). top less number effects (n.effects), forces pareto = TRUE largest top effects displayed. happens, annotation added plot help clarify effects displayed. cex.annot Character magnification annotations ... Additional graphical parameters (see par) used constructing plot.

title: Pareto plot of effects — parplot
text: cutoff values displayed plot labeled “”, margin error, “SME”, simultaneous margin error. specified using crtivals, obtained using 1-alpha quantiles reference distribution absolute pseudo-\(t\) ratios. based distribution \(|t|\). SME based distribution maximum \(|t|\) whole set null effects. determining cutoff values, parplot tries avoid re-simulating reference distribution. Specifically, global variable .Last.ref.dist exists, contents match given method number effects, used reference distribution. Similarly, refdist supplied, used (without checking). suitable reference distribution found, simulated via ref.dist, arguments sim.opts added. critvals supplied, specified values used SME: reference distribution needed, hence method, alpha, refdist ignored. plot scaled cutoff always shows. SME cutoff visible observed effect near exceeds boundary. numeric values SME also shown annotation plot.

what: Analysis of effects from screening experiments — ref.dist
title: Analysis of effects from screening experiments — ref.dist
text: functions facilitate making inferences based effect estimates unreplicated experiment, withn underlying effect-sparsity model.

title: Analysis of effects from screening experiments — ref.dist
code: ref.dist(method, n.effects, nsets, save = TRUE)  eff.test(effects, method = "Zahn", pareto = TRUE, refdist, save = TRUE)

title: Analysis of effects from screening experiments — ref.dist
text: method method use determining reference line, curve, /critical values. must name provided pseudo-standard-error method (see PSE), compatible user-supplied one. n.effects Integer number effects estimated. nsets number complete-null samples size n.effects simulated. omitted, nsets determined total number simulated effects 40,000. save Logical value. TRUE, simulated reference distribution saved workspace .Last.ref.dist. routines package try avoid re-simulating reference distribution .Last.refdist exists matches current method n.effects. effects Vector observed effects tested reference distribution. pareto Logical value. TRUE, effects presented decreasing order absolute size. refdist result previous call ref.dist, case user wishes manually supply previously simulated reference distribution. Note however eff.test automatically reuse .Last.ref.dist available matches.

title: Analysis of effects from screening experiments — ref.dist
text: ref.dist simulates samples effects standard normal dstribution. sample, pseudo standaerd error (PSE) effects (typically kind outlier-resistant estimate SD) obtained via call PSE specified method. absolute \(t\) values obtained ratios simulated effects PSE, well maxima absolute \(t\) values. Quantiles tail areas simulated distributions form reference obtaining critical values P values testing observed sample effects. eff.test performs traditional-style analysis observed sample effects. outputs effects, PSE, \(t\) ratios; uses tail areas associated reference distribution compute individual simultaneous \(P\) values. simultaneous \(P\) values implement multiplicity correction type-errors occurring among tests.

title: Analysis of effects from screening experiments — ref.dist
text: ref.dist returns object class "eff_refdist" -- structurally, list elements abst (absolute values simulated \(t\) statistics), max.abst (sample maxima abst), sig (signature form method_n.effects). print method class displays summary.  eff.test returns data.frame containing estimates, \(t ratios\), estimated P values tail areas abst max.abst reference distribution.

title: Yates's algorithm — yates
text: Implementations Yates's method obtaining factor effects; reverse Yates's method recovering response values; generalization balanced unreplicated experiments two-level factors.

title: Yates's algorithm — yates
code: yates(y, labels = LETTERS, sep = "") gyates(y, nlevels, basis = "poly")

title: Yates's algorithm — yates
text: y Numeric vector response values effects, standard order. See Details. labels Character labels 2-level factors use y contains resoponse values. first \(log_2(n)\) used, \(n\) length(y). sep Character use labels interaction effects. nlevels Numeric vector numbers levels. number observations assumed prod(nlevels). basis Character value vector specifying method use generate orthonormal contrasts. Built-ones include "poly" "helmert", user may create others. elements basis recycled cyclically needed.

title: Yates's algorithm — yates
text: functions implement method computing factor effects balanced, unreplicated designs without need matrix predictor levels. Instead, responses must arranged standard order. method described Yates (1937) case factors two levels (implemented yates), generalization (gyates) can found Good (1958). described Drum (2005). implementation, gyates() uses orthonormal (unitary) matrices, rather keeping track needed divisors. Standard order (also called Yates order) first factor varies fastest last varies slowest. expand.grid function creates factor combinations standard order. yates function experiments factors two levels. returned effects also standard order: default labels yates, order returned effects (intercept), , B, AB, C, AC, BC, ABC, D, etc.: note absence presence factor proceeds standard order. yates gyates, length y one less expected, y assumed set effects, without intercept. instance, algorithm reversed response values recovered effects. Since intercept absent, mean arbitrary. y "mean" attribute, mean adjusted value; otherwise, recovered responses mean zero. gyates, values nlevels basis saved attributes. subsequent call returned effects, values used override nlevels basis arguments supplied user. Effects scaled variance. yates, apply convention design texts, e.g., Box et al. (2005): effect = (mean "+" level) - (mean "-" level), twice regression coefficient one obtains regressing y predictors -1s +1s. gyates, effects computed using orthonormal contrasts, making squared effects equal ANOVA sums squares. effects reversed, scaling assumed. Also, elements y independent, effects. two basis functions supplied "poly" "helmert", based contr.poly contr.helmert respectively. Users may create custom basis, say "foo", writing function foo_gyb = function(k) {...}, supplying basis = "foo" call. function return k k matrix first column equal 1/sqrt(k) orthonormal contrasts remaining columns.

title: Yates's algorithm — yates
text: length(y) power two (yates) product nlevels (gyates), vector length(y) - 1 effects returned (intercept omitted). addition, returned value "mean" attribute set equal mean(y). effects yates named standard order using labels provided. effects gyates labeled using patterns characters .123456789. . label indicates factor whose effect play. illustration, 3 factors, effect named .1. first-order effect second factor, one named 23. interaction second-order effect first factor third-order effect second factor. length(y) one less power two product levels, vector one longer response values returned. names returned responses symbol combinations -+ yates, 123456789 gyates. example, yates length(y) = 7, returned values labeled ---, +--, -+-, ++-, --+, +-+, -++, +++; gyates 5 effects nlevels = c(3, 2), returned effects labeled 11, 21, 31, 12, 22, 32.

title: Yates's algorithm — yates
text: Box, GEP, Hunter, JS, Hunter, WG (2005) Statistics Experimenters (2nd ed) New York: John Wiley & Sons Drum, M (2005) Yates's Algorithm. Encyclopedia Biostatistics, 8. Wiley. title: Yates's algorithm — yates
